advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://mayura.jp/blog" target="_blank">Mayura Labo</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert price list:<br><br> 16K RAM: <b>$399</b> (kit) <b>$459</b> (assembled)<br> Parity option: <b>$39</b> (kit) <b>$59</b> (assembled)<br> Floating point board: <b>$259</b> (kit) <b>$359</b> (assembled)<br> Z80 board: <b>$199</b> (kit) <b>$259</b> (assembled)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE ACCESSORIES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There are more people in more places making more accessories and peripherals for Apples than for any other personal computer in the world.<br> Thanks to those people - in hundreds of independant companies - who can make the humblest 1978 Apple II turn tricks that are still on IBM's Wish List for 1984.<br> But now we're coming out with our very own line of peripherals and accessories for Apple personal computers... </font><br><br> The dual language of Apple: In the same advert, Apple thanks the companies manufacturing Apple compatible peripherals and asks its customers to buy only Apple peripherals in the future.... </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUSTAR AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar standard features in 1983:<br> - 350 KB / 750 KB / 1.5 MB workstation disk capacities<br> - 10 to 144 MB storage options<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Compustar is built and backed by the company that's been in the microcomputer business as long as microcomputers have been in business. Would you trust your business to anything less?</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> BRAZILIAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.museo8bits.com" target="_blank">www.museo8bits.com</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT FS II, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 COLECO CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com/digitize/items/" target="_blank">Digitize, Textfiles.com</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert from the ILLEL store</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROUD FATHER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.console-picture-page.de" target="_blank">www.console-picture-page.de</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #6</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to its optional modem, the TO-7/70 could be connected to the Teletel communication network. This skilled photograph is browsing the Liberation (popular french newspaper) site. <br><br> But there are still no cables shown here ! How the whole system is running ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (OCTOBER, 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>''Particuliar sign : painter and musician''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil 3: three micro-computers in one!"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the home version of the Goupil 3, with only RGB video output and cassette interface. <br><br> What a lucky girl ! Her father offered her a fantastic game machine (the game pictured here must be the only one available for the Goupil 3). This system is perfectly adapted to her small fingers and so delicate knees (have a look at this enormous keyboard, man !).<br> The father must have been working for S.M.T. (manufacturer of the Goupil), as I don't see any other logical explanation. No one would have made this to his child without fearing eternal reproaches.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The new revolutionnary modular system" <br><br> So you say... <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence" <br><br> Not less ! </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>As it's often the case with these promotional pictures, the whole scene sounds fake and so... unreal.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN TANDY CATALOGS (1993)</strong></font><br><blockquote>WP-3 model</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST SALES</strong></font><br><blockquote>In July 1985, California Digital sold the Tano at $99. The price would decrease down to $35 while stock last.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ELECTRON USER MAG #1 (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first issue of the official Electron magazine.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://home.iae.nl/users/bverhoev/" target="_blank">The Electron Lives !</a> for the picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In september 1980, over 200,000 Model 1 were sold, more than 50,000 units per month since the computer was launched.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://pcenginefx.com" target="_blank">PC-EngineFX.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Einstein's face probably means: Buy a ZX-81 and you will become a new genius...<p class="petitgris">Karl_Heinz - www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://club.pep.ne.jp/~p.katsu/pasocata/index.html">P.KATSU</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

computer.description:
A quite little strange belgium computer, which appeared under different designs... However, it is strangely similar to the Brazilian MC-1000 Color Computer from CCE.
Vaporware ?
computer.keyboard: 50 rubber keys (blue for the Charlemagne)QWERTY with Basic statements (MC-1000)RESET, CTRL, SPACE, SHIFT, RETURN
computer.name: GEM 1000 Junior Computer / Charlemagne 999
computer.peripherals: JoysticksPrinterFloppy disk (96 kb)Coleco & Atari VCS carts adaptater !

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> GEM 1000</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is one of the versions of the GEM-1000. The case is particular and the 50 rubber keys are blue. Note the power led at the top-right side...</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> THE GEM-1000 - JUNIOR COMPUTER - CHARLEMAGNE 999</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the same computer but the case seems different, and it has 3 names !</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MC-1000 COLOR COMPUTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is the MC-1000 computer from CCE, a brazilian company. It is strangely similar to the GEM Charlemagne... The keys are black and Basic statements are written above them.</blockquote>

computer.sound: AY-3-8910 from General Instruments, 3 channels + white noise
